Of these, 207 patients needed further breast surgery because of inadequate margins, unfavourable pathology or patient preference. Of these, 142 patients proceeded to mastectomy, the surgical removal of the breast, leaving 385 patients, or 50 per cent, who had breast conserving surgery. The number of patients undergoing breast conserving surgery has increased yearly from 45 per cent in 1989 to 58 per cent in 1996.

The messages are clear from this analysis: (1) early prognosis of breast cancer dramatically increases the statistical probability of patients' survival, especially women, and (2) the SBC, having centralised breast cancer services, has demonstrably and conclusively improved the survival rate of breast cancer sufferers. In Australia, breast cancer is traditionally managed by surgeons, most of whom have experience with small numbers of patients in any one year. A report titled Management of primary, operable breast cancer in Victoria (Aust N.Z. J. Surg 1990; volume 60, pages 871-8) notes that `only four per cent of surgeons saw over 20 patients with breast cancer per year in Victoria'.

The SBC is achieving its goals in centralising expertise to achieve comparable long-term results while optimising a conservative surgical approach and providing an efficient, integrated service. The fourfold increase in numbers presenting to the SBC over this six-year period in itself indicated the acceptance of the clinic and its integrated approach. The SBC's approach has enabled excellent efficiency and treatment, with surgery being performed within 11 days of presentation. They have been able to achieve excellent results by international and national standards, demonstrating the effectiveness of the multidisciplinary approach and confirming the benefits of a specialised unit for the treatment of breast cancer. The SBC is an ideal clinic integrating the many disciplines required to effectively treat this disease and also providing effective breast screening.

For the sake of all breast cancer victims, I strongly urge other states to develop more clinics like the SBC. I salute once again the great work of Professor David Gillett, Catherine Kennedy and all the staff of the Strathfield Breast Centre. Finally, I stress the importance of all women regularly undergoing medical examinations to exclude the presence of breast cancer.

talk.start.para: —One of the disadvantages of public office and our commitment to represent our constituents in this House is that at times we cannot be in attendance on occasions of our choice. Today, I would have chosen to share my day with the many hundreds of people in my electorate of Forde who paid respect to a man who gave much of his life to the shire of Boonah—a man who was respected and loved by many. Jim Pennell CBE lost his fight against cancer last Wednesday, 18 August, surrounded by friends and family—his wife Audrey, daughter Valerie, and sons Graeme and Doug. He was 71 years young.

speech.para: Jim was involved in the community before his election to the Boonah Shire Council in 1961 and went on to serve a full 12 terms of council. He also chalked up the record of being the longest serving member in Boonah's history. Jim's encouragement of others in local council was unstinting. I am sure that many of the people that worked for Jim for years would agree that simply sharing time with him was an opportunity to advance their knowledge of local government, which would result in advantaging their own communities. He held a very distinguished record in council and Boonah shire is much the richer for him serving them for so many years. Jim introduced to the Boonah Shire Council the concept of flood-proofing shire roads which were subject to regular damage during wet seasons. He was committed to improving state controlled roads and ensuring that they were either constructed to seal standards or reconstructed to a better standard. He encouraged the use of unemployment schemes to upgrade footpath, kerbs and channelling in Boonah and Kalbar shires.

Jim was also very instrumental in making sure that Boonah had its own airstrip, council depot, council civic centre, council library, cultural centre and bicentennial park. Jim was a great debater and everybody in town knew him for this. He never, ever backed off on an argument. He would actually wear down his most committed opponents. I spent many times arguing points with him, but I can say that nearly all times he won. I would also like to pass on the thoughts of Senator Ian Macdonald, the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government. He would have liked to have been at the funeral today, but he made sure that his good wishes were sent over. He had spent a lot of time with Jim.

On behalf of the community, I want to record in Hansard the commitment that this man gave of his life to a shire. I do not think I have seen any person as committed as Jim was. He was also the state local government chairman and he spent many a time making sure that other shire councillors and mayors in Queensland knew how to run a shire correctly.

I would also like to congratulate two Green Corps projects that I have had in my electorate. The graduation ceremony of the participants took place last week. I would like to thank the two Green Corps groups in Mount Tamborine and Canungra for the restoration work that they have completed for the district. They have restored much of the damage that was done at the Canungra Army base through artillery fire during the war years. They have revegetated plants and streams and so forth. It was great to see the dedication of those young people for the six months work that they gave to our community, and I would like to congratulate them. It is purely voluntary that they nominate to work on our Green Corps projects. Our young people accept such great responsibility, and they have worked their hardest in conditions where, in the last few months in Queensland, as everyone would note, it has been raining. They worked throughout those times. I would like to thank Drizabone and the Australian Coat Company for sponsoring these young people and making sure that they had adequate cover by supplying coats and hats to our teams.

talk.start.para: —I note the outstanding endorsement I am receiving from the government benches, particularly from the Chief Government Whip, who is a great friend and admirer of mine, as he has often said—but he never says it publicly. Tonight I rise to reflect on a couple of issues in relation to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, particularly an article which appeared in today's Financial Review headed `P&O slams dock reforms'. It is an article by Stephen Long which goes through some of the results, so far, of some of the waterfront reform that has been undertaken by the government. I admit that this is only part way down the track and that there is a long way to go, but I would like to read from part of the article:

speech.para: P&O Ports Ltd suffered a slump of 25 percent or more in the number of containers moved per hour at its Australian terminals during the past two to three months.

Management of P&O Ports, which handles more than 40 per cent of the nation's waterfront traffic, attributes the slump in port performance mainly to skills shortages resulting from the deadline for terminating employees imposed on it by the Federal Government.

P&O had to retrench more than a third of its workforce—some 533 people—within 24 hours of registering new enterprise agreements so it could qualify for funds from Maritime Industry Finance Corporation. MIFCo was set up by the Government last year to bankroll redundancies after Patrick Stevedores' Mr Corrigan dumped his unionised workforce.

"It was bloody stupid, really," the managing director of P&O Australia Ltd, Mr Richard Hein, told The Australian Financial Review . "We would have preferred to have a phased reduction in manning levels but we couldn't because of the government constraints."

When we look at the whole issue of waterfront reform, we see that what P&O has highlighted is an example of the way that the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business works. It is very much a matter of a big bang. It is the media circus rather than the policy emphasis. It is a situation where you try to say something grand and do something grander but, at the end of the day, end up in a grand mess. I know from being down on the docks on occasions in Melbourne, and I know from what occurred at that time, that a lot of the promise that was maintained by the minister was subsumed into a result which left Corrigan's company in a mess, the waterfront in a shambles and did not lead to anything like the changes that were hoped for. This big bang approach is something that this minister has tried to bring to a range of areas.
I note today, around his latest sojourn into public policy on the question of a republic, the minister was quoted with respect to the question of the flag. Again I quote:

The Employment Minister, Mr Peter Reith, has launched a direct attack on Mr Peter Costello's core reason for Australia to become a republic and suggested the Treasurer could have a secret agenda to change the flag.
Further into the paper, Michael Gordon, in commenting on this, states:

Peter Reith had the opportunity yesterday to engage seriously in the substance of the republic debate by answering Peter Costello's case that it is really about the symbolism of retaining a foreign head of state.
He abused it, opting instead for opportunistic scaremongering about the flag that, once again, raised questions about his motives.

. . . he suggested the secret agenda of those who spoke about symbols was to ditch the flag. It matters not that the flag is not being voted on in the referendum nor, as Mr Reith himself observed, that the flag is protected by legislation. "You cannot change it except by vote of the people."

We know from earlier comments regarding the question of this minister's view on the republic he has said that he has been consistent throughout—that he has consistently had three different positions; that he has consistently espoused them at the particular time he has held them; and that he has been in a situation where he has held them very truly and firmly, as he has very truly and firmly held beliefs until he has changed them.

I remember the comment I think made by the member for La Trobe, my friend Bob Charles, along the lines that the minister had had more positions on this issue than in the Karma Sutra. I note the member for Ballarat looking across at me; I know that he is aware of those matters in some detail.
Mr Ronaldson interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I know that we would both like to know more about the Karma Sutra , but that is another story. But this does say something about this minister in terms of his positions on policy. As I said, he has been the sort of minister who has been very grand in the statement, but not so grand in the result; always there is the sweeping change, but at the end of the day he is sweeping most of it under the carpet. The sort of things that he has been up to in relation to the republic debate I think really crystallise his positioning—that is, that he has many positions, but not too many beliefs. It does say something about the way he has operated in this government and as part of the Liberal Party.

—I rise tonight prompted by what I regard as a very positive and certainly successful initiative of one of my parliamentary colleagues, the member for Bradfield. Ten days ago, at Abottsleigh, a local high school in his electorate, he sponsored a forum entitled `Drugs and other bruises—don't leave me this way'. The forum was run as a panel discussion and led by some very eminent figures. They included Dr Ian Paterson, who for 20 years or so has been the principal of a local school; Sally Lone from 2BL; and drugs campaigners from all sides of the debate—the Salvation Army, the Woods family, Tony Trimmingham and others.

speech.para: The interesting thing about the forum in the first instance is that it was attended by 550 people—principally parents—from the local community. Members on both sides of the chamber will be familiar with the difficulty of getting ordinary community members to turn out to events such as this. When you get 550 people turning up and packing a school requiring there to be an overflow room with 150 watching on closed circuit TV, it says that the member for Bradfield was clearly scratching an itch, that there is a great thirst among parents for better knowledge and understanding of these issues. They desire to be better informed and to be able to handle the practical problems such as, for example, what do you do when your adolescent children start wanting to attend or, indeed, host parties at which there is a likelihood that drugs will be present.

I just want to commend the member for Bradfield and to say that he poses an interesting question. That is not just, `Why do kids go on to drugs?' Perhaps the more fertile question is, `Why is it that many do not?' I am reminded of Primo Levi, the Italian Jew, who became a Nobel Laureate. He wrote of his experiences in a concentration camp during the Second World War in which many of the prisoners perished. Often, rather than the older ones, it was the younger fit ones who did not survive. Primo Levi posed the question not why did people die but what was it that caused some to survive?

On that point, as we look at this question of young people and drugs—and I know that parents in my electorate of Parramatta and around Australia are asking themselves the question how do I create the sort of environment in which my kids will not make those choices—it is not my purpose tonight to make really strong statements on either side of the enforcement issues associated with drug abuse but purely to ask the question: how do we create this climate where kids prefer other choices?

I want to refer in particular to some remarks made by a gentleman named Keith Waters, who heads an organisation called Care, Communication and Concern. That organisation is primarily based in Melbourne but is running a program in my electorate about which I have previously spoken in the House. That program is called `Handbrake turn' and is principally directed to turning around the lives of juvenile offenders, particularly in the area of motor vehicles. Keith spends his life among young people who have, for whatever reason, gone down the track of criminal behaviour; most of them are drug users.

I said to Keith, `What is it, do you think, that delineates that class of kids who don't go down that track from those who do?' He said, `Well, Ross, in my view, there are three fairly simple indicators,'—and it is not rocket science and it will not, I think, strike any member in the House as being a revolutionary idea. But he said that the first key variable is strong family relationships; that it is an important foundation for a young person to feel a sense of belonging, identity, appreciation and for there to be coherent family relationships. He said that the second thing is that, while young people are at school, for there to be evidence of a strong participation in school—on the academic side but also on sporting, cultural and other extracurricular activities; that that is a good indicator. Finally, he said that he looks for evidence of some other kind of community involvement and attachment, whether it be scouts, some other sporting activity, a particular hobby or interest that causes a person to connect with their local community.

Keith said to me, `If all three of those things are present, I am relatively confident that you will see a young Australian making good choices with their life, and with a ballast that provides a counterweight to the attractions of a drug culture.' But he said, `If one of those things is absent, the younger person is likely to dabble.' He said, `If two are absent, there is a young person at risk.' He said, `If three are absent, they are almost certainly in real trouble.' So I think that is wisdom for us and for this House. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Aged Care, upon notice, on 12 May 1999:

question.para: (1) What criteria must be satisfied before a health service can be covered by the Medicare Benefits Scheme.

(2) Are chiropractic services covered by Medicare; if not, (a) why not, (b) when did a formal review last consider the inclusion of chiropractic services and (c) what is the Government's position on the inclusion of chiropractic and allied health services.
(3) Will the Government conduct formal reviews of the scope of the Medicare Benefits Scheme soon; if not, why not; if so, (a) when and (b) by whom will they be conducted.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Health services are only covered by the Medicare benefits scheme when the service is:

(a) Performed by a registered medical practitioner (or for an optometrical consultation, by a participating optometrist; or for certain oral surgery services and services in the treatment of cleft lip and cleft palate conditions, an eligible dentist); and
(b) "Clinically relevant", ie. generally accepted by the medical profession as being necessary for the appropriate treatment of the patient; and

(c) Among the services listed in the Medicare Benefits Schedule. Before a new service is listed an assessment of its safety, efficacy and cost effectiveness is undertaken by the Medicare Services Advisory Committee (MSAC).
(2) (a) Services provided by chiropractors are not covered by the Medicare benefits arrangements, as chiropractors are not eligible providers.
(b) The last formal review of this matter was in 1985 by the Medicare Benefits Review Committee (Layton Committee).
(c) The Government does not intend to extend the Medicare benefits arrangements to include chiropractic and other allied health services.

(3) There are no plans to review the scope of the Medicare benefits arrangements in relation to allied health services. To extend Medicare benefits coverage to the many allied health services would lead to unsustainable expenditure on Medicare.

subdebateinfo.title: West Australian Regional Forest Agreement: Additions
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 677)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, upon notice, on 2 June 1999:

question.para: (1) What proportion of the additions to the reserve system for the proposed West Australian Regional Forest Agreement (RFA) consists of (a) old growth forest, (b) regrowth forest and (c) woodlands or scrub.
(2) How many hectares of forest included in the original deferred forest areas have now been excluded from the proposed reserve system.
(3) How many hectares of forest outside the original deferred forest areas have now been included in the proposed reserve system.

(4) What are the locations of the places on the interim list of the National Estate in the RFA region that are now outside the announced reserve system and what advice did the Australian Heritage Commission provide on the significance of the places.

talker.name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
Mr Tuckey
talker.role: Forestry and Conservation; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) Old Growth Forest—42.1%
(1) (b) Regrowth Forest1—38%
(1) (c) Woodland—11.2%
Scrub2—8.7%

(2) There were 21,770 hectares of forests and woodlands included in the Deferred Forest Areas for Western Australia agreed between the Commonwealth and the State which have not been included in the RFA reserve system.

(3) There were 130,110 hectares of forest and woodland outside the agreed Deferred Forest Areas which have been included in the RFA reserve system. In addition, 13,600 hectares have been included in the RFA reserve system which had been voluntarily deferred by Western Australia from logging subsequent to the original Deferred Forest Areas agreement.

(4) I have provided Mr Ferguson with a map which identifies the locations of the National Estate places, interim and listed, in the RFA region in relationship to the RFA reserve system and to forest blocks.
The Australian Heritage Commission (AHC) did not provide specific advice on each of the places identified on the map, but made general comment on the following five areas:
Giblett-Hawke Area; D'Entrecasteaux Area; Jane Area; Deep Area; Roe Area.
The Commission identified the natural national estate values contained in these areas.

The AHC concluded that although timber harvesting will have a significant local adverse effect on these values, national estate values were adequately protected at a regional level through a combination of formal and informal CAR reservation, off-reserve protection and mechanisms agreed under the terms of the Agreement.
1 This is forest that is not old growth.
2 Scrub includes: peppermint and coastal health; rocky outcrops; sand dunes; scrub, herb and sedgelands; and, swamps.

subdebateinfo.title: Aged Care Assessment Team: Assessments in Blacktown, New South Wales
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 720)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Aged Care, upon notice, on 8 June 1999:

question.para: Further to the answer to question No 521 (Hansard , 7 June 1999, page 4980) about aged care assessments, in relation to the balance of 369 persons assessed or re-assessed by the Aged Care Assessment Team, what steps are being taken to ensure that this large number of persons outstanding are able to be placed in hostels, nursing homes or Community Options/Community Aged Care Packages.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Aged Care Assessment Teams (ACATs) assess people for a wide range of reasons. ACATs can approve people for residential aged care, including respite care, and Community Care Packages or they can recommend people to receive Home and Community Care Services. Over half the people assessed by an ACAT are recommended to remain in the community with appropriate care supports.

The ACAT assessment results in either a care plan being developed detailing the most appropriate services to meet the care needs of the individual, or the granting of approval for the person to access residential care or a Community Care Package.

The remaining 369 people assessed by the Blacktown ACAT team were not recommended for residential aged care or a Community Care Package. Home and Community Care services other than Community Options may have been utilised.

During the 1996-97 financial year, 51.1% of people assessed by NSW ACATs were recommended to stay at home and 40.9% were recommended for residential care. The Blacktown ACAT team recommended 372 people for residential care. This equates to 46%. This figure is close to the State average for residential care.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 21 June 1999:

question.para: Further to the answer to the question No. 31 (Hansard , 9 December 1998, page 1809) in which the Minister referred to positive discrimination measures within the internal management practices of the Minister's Department, for those measures which are available to and impact on the general public (a) what measures has the Department implemented which could be categorised as positive discrimination, that is, providing preference to certain citizens on the basis of their gender, sexuality, age, race, place of birth or some other personal characteristic, and (b) what are the details and funding commitments in each case.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: The Department of Industry, Science and Resources has implemented the following positive discrimination measures (as described in the honourable member's question) which are available to, and impact on, the general public:
(1) (a) Regional Tourism Program.

(b) The National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Tourism Industry Strategy provides the framework for stakeholders to remove the barriers to the development of indigenous tourism and encourages Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to choose how they wish to participate in the tourism industry. As part of the Strategy, funding has been provided under the Regional Tourism Program to support indigenous tourism development. In 1998-99, $306,000 was provided on a competitive basis for indigenous tourism projects. These projects will enhance regional tourism business opportunities for indigenous Australians, and result in employment and other economic and social benefits.
(2) (a) Science and Technology Awareness Program.

(b) The Science and Technology Awareness Program provides financial support for activities which aim to increase the science and technology awareness of Australians, and meet perceived unfilled needs in science and technology awareness. Two of the Program's target groups are young people and women. In 1998-99 the program provided financial support to a range of projects totalling $1 million.
(3) (a) Telstra Business Women's Awards.

(b) AusIndustry is a sponsor of the Telstra Business Women's Awards, a national awards program designed to acknowledge and recognise the valuable contribution women make to business throughout Australia. The Commonwealth's sponsorship of the Awards in 1999 is for the "AusIndustry Private Sector employing fewer than 100 Employees" category. AusIndustry sponsorship for the 1999 Awards will total $70,000.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Aged Care, upon notice, on 22 June 1999:

question.para: (1) Did the Prime Minister announce that additional funding would be provided to meet the needs of older people who have been caring for their children with disabilities for decades, over and above that provided in the existing Common wealth/State disability agreement; if so, has the Commonwealth specified to the States how to spend the additional funding.

(2) Have community aged care packages been developed to meet the needs of high level clients at the Nursing Home Care Level in the electoral division of Capricornia; if so, will the packages become available in place of existing nursing home beds or in addition to them.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) This matter is not within my portfolio. The question should be referred to the Hon Jocelyn Newman MP, Minister for Family and Community Services.

(2) There is a program called the Extended Aged Care at Home Packages Pilot Program, which aims to test the feasibility of providing care equivalent to high (nursing care) level residential care to people living at home. The pilot is limited to 10 projects, all of which have been approved and are in various stages of development. There are no plans to increase the number of projects until it has been evaluated. The formal evaluation is due to commence later in 1999. The pilot operates by replacing existing high level residential care places for the term of the pilot.
